titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jon P. Gunnemann Files on Ethical Investments at Yale
Gunnemann (Jon P.) Files on Ethical Investments at Yale
titlestmt.author: compiled by William Landis

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 11, 2019 at 09:45

did.unittitle: Jon P. Gunnemann files on ethical investments at Yale

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The files of ethicist Jon P. Gunnemann document a variety of activities on the topic of ethical investing in which he was involved while a graduate student at Yale University. The materials include correspondence, notes, background research files, and reports relating to the work of the Yale Student-Faculty Committee on Responsible Institutional Investment and the seminar on Yale's investments that grew out of the committee's work. The remainder of the collection consists of drafts and notes relating to the book The Ethical Investor: Universities and Corporate Responsibility , written by John G. Simon, Charles W. Powers, and Jon P. Gunnemann as a result of their work in the seminar.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Forms part of Yale Record Group 49 (YRG 49), Papers and projects on Yale.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jon P. Gunnemann Files on Ethical Investments at Yale (RU 1099). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jon P. Gunnemann, a distinguished ethicist, retired in 2008 from Emory University, where he was a faculty member since 1981. He earned an A.B. from Harvard University in 1962, and an M.A. (1969) and Ph.D. (1975) from Yale University. In addition to his position at Emory, he also taught at the Pennsylvania State University from 1970-1976 and at Yale Divinity School from 1976-1981. Dr. Gunnemann's teaching and research have focused on ethics, economics, and politics, and he authored The Moral Meaning of Revolution , co-authored The Ethical Investor , and edited The Nation-State and Transnational Corporations in Conflict , along with many other articles and reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files of ethicist Jon P. Gunnemann document a variety of activities on the topic of ethical investing in which he was involved while a graduate student at Yale University. The materials include correspondence, notes, background research files, and reports relating to the work of the Yale Student-Faculty Committee on Responsible Institutional Investment and the seminar on Yale's investments that grew out of the committee's work. The remainder of the collection consists of drafts and notes relating to the book The Ethical Investor: Universities and Corporate Responsibility , written by John G. Simon, Charles W. Powers, and Jon P. Gunnemann as a result of their work in the seminar.

Beginning in 1968, Gunnemann was a key organizer of the Yale Student-Faculty Committee on Responsible Institutional Investment, which comprised undergraduate and graduate students and several members of the faculty interested primarily in the issue of investments in apartheid-era South Africa. The committee had the support of Yale's President, Kingman Brewster, Jr., and developed guidelines for a socially responsible investment program for Yale. In addition, the committee conceptualized a research seminar on Yale's investments, and sought and received grant funding from the Ford Foundation to offer this course during the 1969-1970 academic year. The seminar was an interdepartmental investigation into the economic, legal, and ethical challenges presented by universities accounting for moral and social issues in the management of their investment porfolios. Gunnemann served as the coordinator of the seminar, which was led by Professors John Simon, Yale Law School, and Charles Powers, Yale Divinity School.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged by activity, there under alphabetically by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly articles and brochures about the investment policies of academic institutions, corporations, and organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by the name of the organization, or in some cases, the author.
